element_texts.text: Completed

Nettie, Yarmouth
Aug. 1 1866
Yarmouth
Wednesday, Aug 1. 1866
My own dearest,
I reached here with little Mary yesterday P.M. after almost two weeks absence in N.H. I really had a very fine visit, though hurried and somewhat tiresome. I have only to regret in reference it that I lost seeing Samuel & going with him to visit Almeda. I do want to see Almeda very much but I cannot think of undertaking it alone. I am ashamed of every day that I have no more strength and power of endurance. George & Fanny both think May has
Completed

grown fat. She has an excellent appetite and enjoys herself much but will be delighted to start for home. She longs to see you all. I found here four letters from yourself, one from Almeda, one from Samuel and one from Hattie Gaylord. I suppose I must write to her now, that she need not expect to see us, for if you do not come, it will not be best to take Hartford on the route home. I think it probable I had better return with Samuel unless he will be later than I want to be. He says in his letter that he shall start for N.H. and Boston, by last of next week. I do not know whether he means to stop in Boston or not. I have written this morning
Completed

asking about it, and shall hear soon I suppose. I wrote two woeful looking epistles to you from Dunbarton, but I deserved much credit for writing at all! For it was such a busy hurried time, I waited one day for May's shawl which was left at  Dea Parker's so I spent two nights-at Capt. Whipple's and they seemed to enjoy it much Sabbath night we went into the burying ground, and May saw the dear little brothers' grave. That seemed to be the great reason why she wanted to go to Dunbarton. She has just been here to say that she took care of Georgie while Aunt Fannie minded uncle George's coat "And I must say mother" she says, "I got rather tired." Georgie is sleeping now. He is very well.
Completed

Monday morning I rode up, with Dea Burnham to Proctor  Hammond's and while I called his boy went out to Dea P.'s and got the shawl. Proctor is sick, and looks sad and discouraged - has two very pretty children. I expected to walk back to Capt. W's calling at Mr. Burnham's on the way, but Mrs Hammond insisted on harnessing the horse to take me back and while we stopped at Mr. Burnham's, who should come but Agnes with Mr. French's horse and chaise. She had started to go to Mr. Hammond's for me  - said she did'nt know that I ran away with Mr. Burnham, so I rode back with her and called at Mr. Colby's and Rowells, and, after dinner Mrs. Whipple came and carried me to Charles Ryders where I took supper, and called at Harris and then Charles took us back to John Kimball's. Tuesday morning John Kimball took us to Manchester and got us nicely started in the cars.  We got on splendidly - nice day and all night - and friends well, and feast of letters when we got - here. Cousin Abby Hutchinson of Westboro' is to spend next Thursday night here, with her husband. They have gone to Montreal & Quebec for a summer trip. I wish I had another picture or two of little John also of little Anna. In fact I wish I had some of the older boys too - I left a picture of John with Aunt & uncle in Pembroke and Proctor Hammond has
Completed

to the other. I could not well help leaving it. They wanted it - very much and at once offered one of their little girl in exchange, so now I have none to leave for father.

 It seems Mr. Holmes does not refuse to preach for you. I shall want to know the result very much. I rejoice to hear of your good prayer meetings. George is feeling stupid and not in a mood for sermonising. I am sorry he is not stronger. Warm weather and study do not seems to be good for him. His good Dr. tells him to exchange but he does not like to, more than half the time. I guess he will go Bangor way for vacation. Fanny wants to go home.
 I am so glad Eliza gets along so well and that the boys are so good. Grandpa has a nice book for me to take home to each of them. "The Bobbin Boy" and "The Signers of the Declaration of Independence". It is about twelve and I must stop. I had about forgotten to thank you for the check. I do not know but we may ride in to Portland this P.M. and get it cashed. I do not think I shall want any more - can tell better after going to
Completed

Portland. I thought I might buy a double shawl if I found I could get one reasonably - perhaps something for a fall dress, and perhaps - nothing. I want to get some handsome present for Fanny. I gave $2.00 to Uncle Rufus wife to buy a book she wanted and I could'nt find in Concord.

    Well, I must stop.
      Your own loving Nettie.

[upside down] Nettie Yarmouth

                       Aug. 1 1866
Completed

Nettie 
Yarmouth
August 3 1866
Yarmouth, August 6, 1866
Dearest Isaac -
I have just written to Hattie Gaylord.  Yours of July 29 came yesterday morning.  It seems Mary Parker is with you now. And you have had Reverend Mr. Holmes for one Sabbath.  I should like to have heard him.  Glad to hear so good tidings again from the children.  I am thinking you must be pretty well tired yourself, with the care so long of the little ones. I have now $46.00 and some cents, and I do not need more.  I went to Portland last Wednesday P.M. and made some purchases amounting
Completed

of about $15.00.  I may buy a double shawl in Boston if there is time.  I hope to hear from Samuel in reply to mine by the first of September-week so I may know when he is
going.  When we came home from Portland we found cousin Abby Hutchinson and her husband of the Westboro Reform School.  They were just returning from a trip to Canada.
They left just yesterday morning for home.  We had a nice visit with them though short.
I am getting some pictures of Father and Mother to send to some of the Dunbarton people.  They will cost $3.00 I suppose.  I shall not send them all to Dunbartons.
I think it likely the boys need some new night shirts. The cloth is all ready and Mary might make them if there seems to be time.  
In haste, Nettie.
Completed

Nettie Yarmouth
August 8 1866
Yarmouth Maine
Wednesday, August 8, 1866.
My Dearest -
I sat down  yesterday morning to write to you, but concluded to delay until today thinking I might hear from Samuel in the mean time and  so have something definite to tell about going home, but no letter has come yet.  I think I mailed the last letter to you Friday and received the last from you Saturday.  
That day I had two nice rides one in the A.M. and one in the P.M. out to North Yarmouth and then down by the seashore with George.  We got out and walked out on a point where we had a fine view of the two rivers, - Cousins
Completed

and Royals* as they empty into the Bay.  It was a high point and the view was very fine up and down the coast.  Sabbath day heard George preach twice.  The afternoon sermon I thought was excellent and appropriate to the time.  Subject: a Christian patriot's duty to his country.  Serving his country now, he thought was serving his God. Text "Render unto Caesar" etc. George was not satisfied with the text, thought his sermon did not really and naturally flow from it, but could not find any more appropriate.
Monday I had another nice ride and early in the morning Dr. Burbank made a long call and left us an invitation to spend Wednesday afternoon there.  Father and all of us are going.  He is a grand old man. His daughter called in the evening. She was on her way to a grand festival of the Good Templars.  It was just across

 Cousins river and Royal river
Completed

the street from here.  She went by invitation, as did George and Fanny.
I did not care to go, so I stayed with the sleeping children. May is always a little discontented without me.  I left her at Mrs. Kimball's in Dunbarton to go to make calls, and when I came back they said she was homesick, but when I went up to bed with her she said "I guess it wasn't homesick, it was only mother-sick." 
Yesterday Reverend Mr. Lord of North Yarmouth and his wife and daughter visited here.  We had a nice time with them.  He has traveled west and knew about Elyria and Oberlin.  Likes Oberlin, spent a Sabbath there.  His daughter, Julia Lord, is teacher of the senior department in a colored school in Washington - five hundred fifty pupils.  Seventy-eight in her department.  Ten teachers in all with a superintendent.  
She brought home a bright sprightly colored girl
Completed

to her mother.  Vacation till September.  She is fine looking and quite interesting.
The weather now is cool and fine.  Father has a fire in his room mornings but the rest of us do not need it.  I feel much better than during the warm weeks we had at first.  And I think May improves.  She is in fine spirits and I imagine a year in New England would give her rosy cheeks.  George and Fanny do everything possible for our comfort, and we feel perfectly at home.
But I think we both long to see the dear ones at our own home. I hope I shall hear from you today and from Samuel also.
It is mail time.
In haste, your own
Nettie
Completed

Yarmouth, Maine
Thursday, August 9, 1866.
Dear Isaac - 
I wrote yesterday, but have since received a letter from you and one from Samuel.  I was feeling quite anxious to hear from home.  The letter was longer on the way than some have been.  
I suppose I had better wait and go home with Samuel now, but I thought he would go next week.  He says he shall leave Boston for the west the first of the week after next, and will write to me next week to tell me just what day to come to Boston and he will meet me at the depot.
Father and George seem very glad of the additional week I have.
Completed

by this arrangement to stay here and we are really enjoying very much.  The weather is cool and fine.  Yesterday we visited at Dr. Burbanks and had a nice time. I do like them. Miss Esther is a very noble girl.  Quick intellectual and very musical - fine singer and has a large class of Piano scholars.
Today we are invited to Mr. Ansel Loring's.  He is George's most intimate friend here, and a fine man.  He lives in the house where mother died.   Friday we expect some young company.  Miss Anna Burbank and a cousin from Portland.
Father has just had a letter from Herbert and Jenny. It seems Herbert is building on his new land and has given up his shop entirely.  Father is pretty comfortable but still has his old trouble and very little strength.
Completed

Give love to Mary and to call the children.  I do so long to see you and be at home again. If I had not written to Samuel that I would wait for him I do not know but I should start alone next week.  But perhaps it is all well as it is.  And I do think May and I are both in better health than we we left home.
Lovingly
Nettie
Completed

Yarmouth
Saturday August 11, 1866
My dearest -
I have just been reading accounts of the  A.B. riot and it makes me feel quite discouraged about our President.  It seems so strange that he should be left to take such a course after his words and deeds during the war.  It seems as if he must have acted from some personal motive instead of being at heart a true patriot.
I think wrote to you Thursday morning before there came two letters from you.  One enclosing the money order which came safely and is now in George's hands.  He will cash it for me.  I do
Completed

not need any more money than that either, unless I should have a chance to by a shawl in Boston which is not very likely. That money order seems to be a very secure affair I should think, as well as convenient.
Thursday afternoon we visited at Mr. Loring's and had a fine time.  May enjoyed it greatly with a little 10 years old daughter of theirs.  Yesterday was a great day with the Free Masons.  They marched in grand procession with martial music to the First Church, where they had an Oration by Reverend E. C. Bowles of Portland. (Universalist) Which was really very able and eloquent. After which they had a dinner in a big tent etc. and more marching and music and a dance in the evening.  We all went over to hear the Oration. 
Your church meeting was yesterday
Completed

Wonder what was done.  Hope you will be directed in just the right and best way.  I hope the good people pray about it.  We know so little shat is best for us.
May is out in the garden with little George.  She longs to see Anna and John as well as the older ones.  She has been writing to Anna, but she says it is "too mean" to send.  I have had half dozen pictures of father and mother copied, chiefly to send to Dunbarton. Expense $2.50.  I do not know as it was best to do it, but some of the people there were anxious for them and father had none, so I offered to pay for them if father would get them taken.  I have sent one to Proctor Hammond and Lewis Wilson and to Capt. Whipple and Dea. Parker.  I bought some cloth for a dress for myself in Portland $6.25 - only an afternoon dress for
Completed

fall - I have had May's shoes mended twice since we came here.  I thought some of getting her a new pair, but rather concluded there is not difference enough in price to make it an object and that she had better wear these out first.
George sits here ( I am in his study) writing sometimes.  He has besides the usual duties tomorrow a funeral to attend of an aged man.  Last Wednesday he attended two funerals one an aged lady, the other a young man.  You have written of no death, I think, since I left.  George will take his vacation next month I think Fanny will go to Dedham with George. Mr. Abbott the other pastor here is already gone with his family also the Baptist preacher.  People do not want George to go till these return, or one of them.
With great love to you all,
Nettie
Completed

Nettie
Yarmouth
August 14, 1866
Yarmouth, Maine
Tuesday, August 14, 1866.
My dearest Isaac -
This is washing day and I have been trying to help a little sweeping and looking after Georgie etc. and came near forgetting that I intended to write to you.  Yesterday came a letter from Samuel saying that I might come to Boston by the morning train next Monday.  It leaves about eight - I believe -  The we can leave Boston Monday night I suppose.  He says they will stop one night at Grafton and Mr. Biscoe's and had written to them that I should be with them.  I suppose I might stop at Westboro just as well and see cousin Lucy and her mother unless it
Completed

would be better to keep with them.

Father seems quite unwell still though better than one would suppose he could be with his troubles.  He feels quite discouraged at times, but never seems gloomy at all - usually in very good spirits.  George is gone for a day or two to attend an Ass. at Minot.  George is needing his vacation.  He is not able to study much.  The weather is delightful not very warm, but sunny and bright.  May and I went yesterday down on the rocks in the River and had a good time.  May thought it was "splendid".  She is playing now with Georgie, the little sprite.  He put my parasol into a pitcher of water this morning, but I guess it is not injured. It is hard to find enough for him to do.
I wish you could meet us in Cleveland, and so you and I together
Completed

select some carpet for our dining room.  We might cover it as our bedroom is covered, with oil cloth round the outside.  What do you think about it?

 I suppose we shall get home next week Wednesday.  And I think we shall both be gladder than since we left, notwithstanding we have so much enjoyed seeing dear friends here.  I cannot help wishing we were nearer each other - only George and Father and me, and we can so seldom meet - I wish I could leave them without saying good bye.  I dread it.
 Perhaps I may not write you again.  We shall be quite busy.  Have some calls to make and I have some mending to do for father and do not know but I may have my dress fitted too.
 We received the "Premium list of continues next page
Completed

Lorain Co Fair".  I suppose it cost you considerable time and labor and will yet till it is over.

Your own Nettie M.

I suppose Samuel and Eliza will go directly to our house with me will they not.  So Eliza will need to have the chamber ready.
Completed

Nettie
Yarmouth
August 16, 1866
Yarmouth -
Thursday August 16, 1866
Dearest 

  How good you are to write so often!  I do thank you very much indeed.  Last week I had five letters or rather four.  The fifth came this week - yesterday - and today came one mailed the thirteenth.
 I should love to see Mary Thurston but do not think it is best to try to do so now - can visit her when I get home.  So Hattie Gaylord is to come to Elyria.  Hard for Anna unless she as a good girl, as I hope she can have.
 I should have liked much to hear good Mr. Wilbur last Sabbath.  I am very glad the family do
Completed

not leave at once.

 I do not understand why Samuel wrote to Percy that he should come this week, though I did myself infer that, from one of his letters to me.  I have written you since he wrote me decidedly about the time and probably you will know before this will reach you that I am to leave Yarmouth next Monday to meet them in Boston and they are to stop one night in Grafton.  So I suppose, if we have no hindrance, we shall be home Wednesday.  You must be very busy and it seems as if you must need me, though I may miscalculate my own importance somewhat.

Love from all.  Georgie is glad of the kisses.  He can smack as well as anybody.
Completed

May seems in fine spirits, though she and I are both longing to be home and see you all.  It rained all day yesterday and bids fair to do so all day today.  George has not yet come home from the Minot Ass.  We were invited to visit yesterday but did not because he was not here. Shall go Saturday instead to Mrs. Loring's  - the wealthy widow lady.  We had several callers yesterday spite of rain and clouds.  One lady brought Fanny some fine looking balls of butter and one brought 12 yards of print for dress.
Will Percy be with us? Elisa will be ready for Samuel and wife I suppose - as they had better go right to our house.
Lovingly 
Nettie
Completed
Great love to the boys. I am glad Wilder can help you - Love also to Mary B and Elisa - Father is quite feeble - does not seem to get better.
Completed

Sabbath, May 5, 1872
Dear Wilder - 
You have to day promised openly to live for Christ.  I do so want to have you like Christ - full of His Spirit.  May your heart be filled with his love and may all around you see that it is so.  I wish you would try to think of ways in which you may show this new love in your heart to those around you. One way certainly is by being more gentle and kind at home and at school and wherever you mingle with others.  And also by being firm as a rock for the right and against the wrong.  Show that you know what you believe as well as in whom you believe.  My heart leaps at the thought that you may, by daily living, studying,
Completed

working and playing like a Christian, not to please yourself, lead Charlie and Eugene and many others to Christ and to a higher and nobler life.  I want them not to say "if Wilder is a Christian, I don't want to be one" but "if being a Christian make Wilder what he is, let me be one too.  Dear Wilder, pray daily that you may be like Christ.
Your loving mother,
Nettie P. Metcalf
Completed

Elyria, Ohio
Monday, December 15, 1856
My very dear Albina:
Long ago did intend to write to you, but many things have conspired to deter me.  I really cannot tell when I did write you, or whether I have written since you wrote to me.  We have been quite busy of late as you may suppose.  We moved into our new house the 26 November.  All our furniture has arrived at last and we begin to feel quite at home and as happy as we could expect to be.  Long, dark shadows have fallen across our way, and life can never seem to us as once it did.  A sense of our loss comes over us sometimes, 
[written up the left side of the page]
from us both.  Do write soon and tell me every thing you can possibly think of.  While Isaac is away I shall need letters you know more than ever. 
Lovingly -
Sister Nettie
Completed

with almost crushing weight, but we feel that we have much to be thankful for.  Little Wilder is very well and fat and happy.  He has only six teeth - says a few words and has taken a few steps alone. Seems to be just about as strong now as both were before being taken sick.  He is not so forward in talking now as Willie was then.  It would do you good to look at his little fat, laughing face.  

O how I should love to see you and your dear ones. I wonder if you are very busy these days.  Do write and tell me what you are about and if you are well and happy.  How much has happened since with saw each other.  O how merciful it is that we do now know what is to happen
Completed

to us beforehand.  We have been feeling very anxious about Mother (as doubtless you and Charles have) for more than a week, but the last news encouraged us very much and we hope to hear next that she is gaining fast.  She must have had a very severe sickness.  I hope she may be even better now than before she was sick.  Do you hear from Almeda often?  She has a hard task to perform.  I hope she and her Rider will have strength equal to their day.  I wish you could look in upon us in our home.  If it were not that Isaac is going West I should really feel quite happy.  I do not think he will
Completed

(Mother - Elyria, 1856 to Aunt Albina)
go before January.

 Thursday Morning  - The letter from Bangor tells us good news.  Dr. McRuen calls mother out of danger.  Anna and the Dr. and Hattie were home last evening and we all rejoiced together over the welcome tidings.  It lifted a weight from our hearts.
Do the children go to school this winter?  Has it been very cold?  
We only finish two rooms  besides the kitchen below and a chamber for Jennie above.  Our sleeping room is prettily furnished and convenient and we live in it principally.  We have in it a large and small bureau, a book case and a lounger and a little stand.  The wash stand is a fixture in a corner of the room.

How I should love to see Mary.  I am glad she remembers our little Mayo. May they meet at last.  Love to you all.
Completed

April 1, 1858 -
Dear Albina -
I must write a little though with Charly in my arms.  He is very well now though requiring more attention than before he was sick.  We are thinking to wean him before warm weather but I dread it.  I think it will be more of a task than with any one of the other children.  Wilder and Percy play out of doors a great part of the day now.  A box of sand, that happened to be at the door affords them great amusement and employment.  Libby is not very well now, so, for the good of the walk, she has been up here every morning for a number of days.  Her eyes are
Completed

very troublesome - so weak she cannot go to school at all.  She studies at home whenever they are comfortable enough to admit of it.  Hattie has been up to day also and took dinner with us.  She hopes she has found the Savior, as do many others here.  We are enjoying the meetings here very much.  Mother and I cannot always go, but we feel that in God much when absent.  We were very glad to hear so good news from Milo.  O when we remember how willing God is to save and how he has promised answer to the prayer of faith.  How can we help going to Him continually with the cares of those whom we love, who are not yet devoted and
Completed

Him.  "If we abide in Him and His words abide in us, we may ask what we will and it shall be done unto us."  I was struck by the remark of a minister the other day that he believes no sinner was every converted except in answer to the faithful prayer of some Christian.  Does not this make us feel the weight of our responsibility.  

  I hope Charles and Josie will learn to love Jesus now.  Is will never be easier and Jesus loves to bless children and they will never be sorry for giving Him their early years.
 I wish you would come out here with Charles next fall.  We should love to see you very much indeed.
Completed

Love to Charles.  We all think much of him and hope and pray that the love of Christ may be shed abroad in his heart, and that he may soon rejoice in this glorious freedom of the Son of God.  

  I must stop - many thanks for your letter.  Do write again soon.

Lovingly,
Nettie.
Completed

This is the first day of June.  Our precious little Mayo was born four years ago.
My dear Mother -
We were very glad indeed to hear from you and Percie and all the rest.  Such good news of the baby is really worth while - and when Albina nurses her does she not, and that is something new and pleasant.  I do hope the children will be well all the summer.  Little Wilder is very well now and out doors at almost all the pleasant days, but he will pick off the tulips, and moreover appears to have the Irish man's idea that the beans come up wrong.  But we mean to teach him to keep his little mischievous fingers away from the flowers.  He trots from one to the other pointing and teach and talking just as fast as he can.  We can
Completed

not understand him very well of course.  But he is learning to talk - he says "dear papa" and "yes ma'am" and "how do" very prettily - tries to say Aunty, etc.
I have a dressmaker here today finishing a dress.  She has just been making one for Anna.  O, I wish you could see the flowers in our yard.  They look prettily now and will better still by and by .  We took tea at Anna's last week Wednesday, with Rev. D.M. Lathrop of New Haven.  The first Presbyterian Minister of Elyria and now the Agent of the Du Quoin Seminary - an interesting man.  Mr. and Mrs. Prior were there too.
We all like the names very much indeed.  Love to Charles and Albina and all the dear children.
Completed

You mentioned not closing up school till five o'clock.  What time do you begin?  And how much intermission have you?  I advise you by no means to exceed you regular time.  You should keep 6 hours a day and 6 only.  Be particular.  You will get no thanks for keeping seven hours or six and one half hours.  On the contrary, people will be less pleased to have the school prolong than to have it closed promptly at the time.  And you lose or worse than lose all P.M. time.  Some teachers say they can't get those in the regular time. But they can and should.  A teacher can get thro at any hour he pleases by making the proper calculations.  Do you go home at noon?  Your mother wishes to say to you if the water which you have to drink is bad, you may find it best to drink tea.  She would have you do so, if promotive of your health.

How do you spell Niagara?  We noticed you spelt it wrong in your letter.  Spelling the last syllable ria.
Completed

In regard to corporeal punishment in school, your mother thinks you better not resort to it without knowing what are the customs of other teachers in this respect.  I concur in this.  Endeavor, if possible, to keep up school in subjection without the rod at all.
Completed

2.
evening, and for 36 hours before the wind blew like a hurricane, whirling the feathering flashes most unmercifully and piling them in huge drifts such as have not been seen here for many a year, if ever.  I never saw old Boreas so perfectly furious.  Not till about sun rising this morning, did he cease operations, and it really seemed strange and delightful to look out of doors and find all quiet.  The "breaking-out-teams" soon began to pass, and about quarter past one, supposing the roads would be passable, I started in a sleigh for home.

  We had proceeded by a short distance before the poor horse was immovably fixed in a snow drift, which, before shoveling, was 15 feet high.  A kind neighbor came to help release the struggling beast from the snow and from the sleigh and then the men drew the sleigh while I moved from side to side to prevent an overturn.  Then we went on a short distance farther and the same scene was enacted again, on a more magnificent
Completed

magnificent scale, till we were forced to stop entirely, and wait for sleds to go through before us.  I went into a house nearby till the road could be broken out; and it was half past four ere I reached home.  But I enjoyed the long visit finally commencing with prized friends and playing and talking with little prattlens.  However, I am right glad to find myself once more at home.  The warm welcome from father, mother and Jenny made me thank Heaven again for dear friends - home friends. 

I found another letter waiting for me making the sixth in the year.
I must wish you a "Happy New Year". I have, many times before this, in my heart.  I shall look anxiously for your next letter. We should like to know as definitely as convenient, when we may hope to see you, so that we may send to George.  More glad that I shall be to see you again, the time has seemed so long. 

Most truly yours,
Antoinette
Completed

at top left: Mrs Hale  Gilmanton N.H.  Oct. 12 1850
Dunbarton
at top right: Elyria Union Schools
image of Gilmanton Academy
Oct. 3. '50
My dear Antoinette.
Your kind sad letter was here to greet me on my return to Gilmanton.  Thank you for it.  I almost feared I should not hear from you again. -
And has death really entered your little circle?
How ill you could afford to spare that darling brother, but He to whom he belongs had higher claims and you did not fear.
Completed

did you trust him in His hands?  You would not wish the disposal to be left to you.

And then the blessed hope of soon rejoining him in another home.  How you should praise God for that.
 And is my dear A learning "useful lessons"?  May she become wise under this teaching of her great Master above.  After a near acquaintance with death especially if it be in youth.  I think life never looks again precisely as it did before.  Its flowers seem more fading, it's sunshine more uncertain.
 Well, it is good to "feel" that in the world we must have tribulations but we will also remember to "be of good cheer," as our Savior has commanded us.  Our highest joys are often connected with our severest trials.  May you and your dear parents find it so, to whom please tender my regard and sympathy.
 Yes, dear A.  I am again at Gilmanton and thinking you might not have seen the old Academy in print.  I have taken this little sheet from which to send you my thoughts.  We have a larger school, but I

[Left-hand side] Let me hear from you again soon.
Completed

am in the school room but two hours daily.

  Our Father grants us some small token of His favor - our labor seems not to be entirely unblest as regards the souls of our beloved pupils. One, at least we hope, has found peace this time and some others are more or less inclined to seek the salvation of their souls among the young ladies a large number are indulging hopes.  In addition to our second meeting, a  prayer meeting orchestrated by themselves has been held. They enjoy it very much and I think it exerts a very favorable influence.
 I spend much of my time in calling upon the young ladies at their rooms, and conversing with them upon various subjects.  The health of my children was such as to prevent my being here at the commencement of the term and made me unwilling to so connect myself with the school that I could not have should it be necessary.  Eliza claimed me in the summer.  She is now well, with a little infant a few weeks old. I do not remember whether I told you of Henry's ill health in my last.  It caused me great anxiety for a time but he is never very much better and we hope will be
Completed

entirely restored. I expect him here every day, to spend the remainder of the Autumn. His business is the care of his health, for the present.

    F. has charged me never to mention his name to you, as you have asked, but, I will just tell you that he is at Chester, clerk in his Uncle Melvin's store. I cannot tell you more without seeing you.
  Dear A, you will always be dear to me. I can hardly tell why, but you have always been peculiarly so, and while you value my letters at all, and will give me yours in exchange, you will hear from me occasionally, if circumstances permit.

[left-hand side] the present, past and future in our thoughts. Will it ever be? Yours sincerely,  L.F. Hale.

C.E. Beecher Brooklyn N.Y.
Dec. 9 1847
Lockport Ill.

                                                                                                           Brooklyn, N.Y. Dec. 9 1847

Dear Miss Putnam,

                      Gov. Slade is making up the many accounts for the first annual Report of the Board if N.P.E. & he wishes, if any of you design to return any money paid for travelling expenses, that you would do it, if possible, in the month of December - enclosing it in a letter, to Rev. C.E. Stowe - Walnut Hills - Ohio.  Those that have borrowed Society money are especially requested to return it, if possible, in December. We do not wish to urge this on any one, but we wish you to know that on account of gainsayers, it will be of service to our cause to reduce the expenses of our first Class as much as possible, as they will be presented in our first published Report.
                  I think it probable that next Spring, we shall send teachers, two together, to some very destitute places, where they will keep home, & their expenses be paid not by the Board, but by money raised for this express purpose. If you know of any place near you, where such a plan would work well, I wish you would write to me, directing to Brooklyn, N.Y. till Jan. 15th  & after that, to Hartford, Ct.
                                                                                                               Gov. Slade & all of us have been greatly
Completed

cheered by accounts received from our first Class. They have more than fulfilled our hopes, and next summer, I design to go around & see them all. I have not time to write you myself & by the hand of a friend, send you my love & blessing.

                                                                                                                                Ever your friend,
                                                                                                                                  C.E. Beecher

P.S. Those teachers to whom the Secretaries at Chicago, Milwaukee & Indianapolis gave money on their arrival, must count that as money borrowed of the society, unless it was afterwards spent for travelling expenses. 
Dear Miss Putnam - We do not wish those who are situated as you are to return any of the money for trav. expenses out as you are on missionary ground. I send this to enquire what you think about the plan of having two live together & keep house in such a place as prior Roberts is in.

   Suppose I receive funds enough to make you & her comfortable as housekeepers there & you spend your time when not in school, in visiting & in trying to do good among the people as well as the children. Do you not suppose you could
Completed

do more good than in establishing a school at Ottawa or any other place in not so much of a Missionary field? I think I shall visit Chicago in the Spring & I am receiving funds this winter to keep our teachers comfortable in place when the people do not make them so.

   Let me know what you think would be the best way of managing on such a field as the one you are in if money is furnished to do with. Write me about your health as Prior Roberts writes that you are not very well. What seems to be the matter?
    Write as soon as you receive this & direct to this place. After the middle of Jany direct to Hartford Conn.
                                                                                          Yours very affly
                                                                                        C.E. Beecher

Homer
March 22 "50
Miss Putnam  Dr Madam this will inform you that through the mercy of our covenant God we still are numbered with the living and enjoy health, No particular change has taken place in our family Since you last heard from us, except that Warren was married this present week, to a lady you was not I think aquainted with, Miss McGoveny. Solomon is living at home, I am Pastor of the Church in this place. We all wish to see you very much, and you will never cease to live in our memories and affections, you may not have been informed of Mrs Wm Padocks sickness  She has been sick the most of the winder, but is now recovering, My present Object in writing is in behalf of the directors of our school, they are very anxious to hear you return to our place for the purpose of instructing our school, if you could think it your duty to to do so they propose to refund in part and perhaps the whole in some say the expenses of coming. The directors are Wm Wells, Wm Padock, Mr Kirkam  I believe so far as I know there is a general desire for you to return to our place. The views of our people here, with regard to teachers and there wages, have very much improved

S. Knapp  Homer ILL
March 20 1850  Dunbarton

Since you first became aquainted with us, scarcely any female thinks of teaching short of $2.00 dollars per week. Well qualified teachers may get more.  If you are at liberty I would give it as my Opinion you need not hesitate to come & with the purpose of remaining, I will my self assume a large responsibility in the whole matter so that if you regard me reliable you may rely upon me to look after your interests as I do my own family  I say this because I know the distance that intervenes between this and you place and something what would naturaly be your feelings and those of your parents in coming to reside so far from the Paternal rooff?  I wish you to understand that you have warm friends in this place, It may be however that you are under other engagements and cannot accede to our wishes, you will pleas write us amediately, you will pleas to rememnber me affectionately to your Parents.  You will observe that the name of our Town is changed  I add no more but remane your affectionate friend.   S. Knapp

on side in different handwriting:
Dear A.  I suppose you will not hesitate, how to reply to this letter. Remember your parents to them (Mr & Mrs K) in Christian affection.  How do you succeed with so many scholars? I am afraid it will be too hard for you  I hope they will increase your wages - they certainly ought to make it $3   Mother  Thursday eve.

Oliver Wilson is quite an invalid has not been able to go to church for a year I think.  I have not seen any of Fathers family for nearly a week. Mother and Louise are both in poor health, L. will go West - to spend the winter with Mary if nothing prevents, she has been delicate for a year and I fear will have a consumption if she is not careful, the Dr. says all she wants is to have more blood her face is nearly as white as this paper,  Abbie is at Derry at school, she boards at Uncle Leonard Parkers he is settled there now, at the upper village  Helen Hammond is married to a man by the name of Marshall (no one you knew) and has a son  Abbie Wilson Colby has a daughter  Mrs Charles Kimball has two little girls Sadie 3 years old and Anna one,  Mrs Proctor Hammond has a son two weeks old  Eliza Mills has a son and alas has no husband to rejoice

over its birth it is a great affliction to the family I am truly sorry for them and for her that she should be left to sin in that way. Your Father visited D. in the spring he was not very well and did not visit as much as he would have done had had it been warmer weather he spoke to us a part of the Sabbath I can realize how sad it must seem to you that your dear old home is occupied by new faces, - you must miss your Mother's letters so much, no one can take a mothers place, it seemed sad to us that she should be taken so soon after she left us but she has found a better country even an heavenly.
A year since we had a letter from you brother George giving us a warm invitation to visit him but we have not been able to do so, tho' I know of no friend I should love better to see.
We like our new minister very much he reminds us of your brother George

in his style, and to see him walking a little way off looks like him, but they do not look at all alike in the face he has a pleasant family consisting of his wife and her sister and two little daughters one six and the other four years old.

Mrs. Leroy Mills fell on the door step at church three weeks since and broke her arm, she is recovering.
 Mrs. Wate (the old lady) hung herself some three months since it is thot she was insane at the time as she had been very low spirited for some time, she and James lived where Mr. Bunten used to.

times at my wits end to find stories for her.

John has returned and on learning to whom I am writing says I ought to be ashamed that I have neglected it so long, I think so too. When I told him what I had written he advised me not to go back to the time of Adam & eve for news. I hope a part of it will be interesting to you. Many thanks for your picture it is a very good one and I will prize it very much. we hope sometime to see you at Dunbarton. your old friends all remember you and would send much love did they know I was writing I saw old Mrs. Harris a few weeks since at Manchester she spoke of you, she lives with Mrs. Lewis Harris but she is gone south to look after his property there and Mary Ann Caldwell is staying with the old lady.

Excuse all that I have written that is not interesting and if you can overlook
[left-hand side] my long delay I should love very much to hear from you again. tell me all about the children.

Dunbarton Oct. 24th 1862

Dear Friend Nettie:-

               I am almost ashamed to attempt an apology for my almost unpardonable delay in answering your welcome letter. I thought then I would answer it without delay but John was quite sick at the time and had so many cares I put it off and I have kept doing till tonight. I was moved as the Quakers say, to go at once and write you. I am all alone, little Mary has gone to sleep taking quite a care from my mind. John has gone to the prayer meeting, the Baptists are holding a series of meetings in the neighborhood we are all very well, it has been a very busy summer with us, and we still have plenty to do in preparing for 

[left-hand side] John wishes to be remembered to you - the other family also send love the all remember you with much affection. I still think of the summer you taught our school as one of the happiest of my school life and have thot many times that I wished to thank you for your faithfulness to us. Do write me again. Yours with much love Sarah P. Kimball
Completed

winter. The war has been the chief topic of interest - and is still. some have enlisted whom you knew Henry & Horace Caldwell Henry went as Capt. and died at Falmouth Pa. in the summer, of fever Horace is in the Hospital at Newport R.I. so also us David Jameson one of Mr. Hugh Jameson's sons.

Henry and Fred Wate and Frank Putney some of your old scholars, Frank Mills enlisted and was discharged having wounded himself in the hand while cleaning a pistol, Leonard Wilson one of Lewis W's sons, that is all I think of that you would know. I forget Will. Bunten who has gone as Capt. in the 14th and Bradford Burnham.
 I believe our quota of nine months men is not quite full they offer 200 dollars bounty for volunteers for both calls. about half of the enrolled men, some of them the strongest and most able-bodied men in town, have got certificates of exemption from military duty on plea of some ailment or other, the
Completed

examining physician was either knave of fool I do not know which however I do not worry about John being drafted but I do wish this dreadful war was at an end, we have a Soldier's Aid Society and have done something for the Soldiers tho' not as much as some towns.

Agnes and Gilbert French are at last made one flesh, as you may have heard. Gilbert and Capt. Whipple have bought Mr. Caldwell's place and Mr. Caldwell has bought Capt. Whipples and they (the Browns Frenchs etc.) live in great peace. Mary Eliza Caldwell's husband has enlisted and O presume she will spend a part of the time at home. Olive is not yet married. Sarah Wate is engaged to Horace Caldwell. Will Bunten was married just before he left and his wife has gone to Washington with him. I fear I shall write you some stale news and much that you have heard before but as I do not know what you may have heard I will
Completed

venture to write all I think of.
I presume you may have heard of the death of Mr. Wm. Whipple, nearly a year since, he died of inflammation of the lungs caused in part by neglecting to shut off the gas in the room where he slept at Manchester. Mrs. W. and her two little boys live where Mr. J. Colby used to at the center of the town. Harris Ryder is still an invalid. I have not seen him at church for some weeks sometimes he is much better and does some work but any over exertion is generally followed by another sick turn he has a difficulty of the heart I believe his Father is dead, so also is Capt. Larkum of Beverly whom you may remember married Mrs. Ryders sister.
Miss Elizabeth Wilson has also gone to her rest, Amanda Wilson died last week at Manchester of fever her illness was short she was the only daughter of Mr. Lewis Wilson.

Eliza Paddock
Homer July 15. 1863

Homer July 10th 1863
My dear Mrs. M.

   It is now nearly two months since I received your welcome letter containing your picture. I was very much surprised when I received your letter for I thought that you had entirely forgotten that we were still in existence.
     We were very glad however that you still remembered old friends. Oh how I wish I could come and see you and those dear little ones or that you might make us a visit.
 Cannot you come I am sure no one
Completed

would be more welcome than yourself. We should be delighted to see you. Let your next letter say that you will come.

  We are all generally well. Mother's health was quite poor in the spring but is now very much improved. we keep no girl and Mother & I do the house work.
  By the way I would inform you that we had had an addition to our family since I wrote you last - not a baby but a little girl seven years old that Mother has adopted from the Home of the Friendless in Chicago.
    You enquired as to Miss Slate's whereabouts she is at Athens (a small village about seven miles from here) taking care of children for a Mr. Singer.
 We have had but little rain this summer and every thing seems to be drying up. The roads are very dirty. It has rained some today but not enough to do any good.
   We are building a new church here it stands almost on the very spot the old
Completed

school home that you taught in used to stand, and our school house stands a few steps west of it. The church is to be finished in three or four weeks.

 I shall be so glad when it is done.
 Uncle Walter's family is well. I wish you could see that blackeyed boy Elmer, he is such a rogue. We all love him dearly.
  Uncle is going to Michigan on a visit after harvest and says if he finds a farm to suit him he shall go there to live. I hope the land will look miserably poor to him for I should be sorry to have him move.
  I think I shall not have time to write much more as I have two or three more unanswered letters before me.
   Hoping that you will excuse mistakes and answer very soon & will bid you
                                                                                                  Adieu
                                                                                                  Eliza Paddock

(Mother and Father send much love)
Completed

Miss Mary Dascomb
Sept. 24 1863
Oberlin. Friday Night
Sept 24th 1863

In the greatest haste my dear Mrs Netty, I write you a line by Mr Parker. I have meditated writing you for a long time the first "spare" (definition?) time (wonder if I can't inveigh another time in so as to make these times in a row), (excuse me). that I had. How I have had a remarkably spare time this week. Could have got along without it maybe  have been on my back since Sunday night, and am just up for today.  I am staying at Aunty Clarke's with Ella, while Aunty goes to Toledo on a visit to Willie. That will take about six weeks. Then
Completed

a little while at home with Pa and he leaves for Hillsdale, leaving his bereaved family behind (My writing looks wild) !  I shall not pounce down upon you without leave, but when I find that I can leave home comfortably, I shall write to inquire into your domestic affairs, and if the Fates be propitious I shall gladly devote myself to satisfying and being satisfied at your most hospitable home.  Meanwhile, if a chance occurs of a ride to Oberlin, please come. our house (Dascomb Cottage) will now, or soon most comfortably and gladly welcome you into the room prepared for ?. Come and see it. I wish especially that you would stay over the Sabbath there is a deep religious interest here now, and many are hoping
Completed

and praying for a Revival. We all need it. Pray God it may come in all our hearts.

    Most hastily, but Lovingly 
                                   Your
                                      Mary D.

Love to all the family, and inquiring friends.
Completed

Miss Mary Dascomb
Oct 14 1863

                                                                                            Oberlin, Lorain Co. Ohio.
                                                                                                         Wed. Oct 14th. 1863.

Dear Mr. Metcalf.

                            An old classmate of mine (oh me! either the old or the of mine are superfluous)  asked me the other day of the Board of Directors on Elyria had written regulations for their Schools. I was not certain but volunteered to find out, and if such existed to beg one for him. He expects to be at the head of quite a large school, furnished I believe entirely with Oberlin Teachers, and wished all the light possible on the best method of proceeding.
   So much for business - now for pleasure! How are you all? I hear you have a boarder, and if you had been a whit less kind to me, I might be jealous of her privileges, but as it is,
Completed

I haven't the slightest room for such feelings. I can scarcely wait to see you again. Some changes have taken place - two of my pupils have gone forever. One well-prepared - the other, I fear not, though the poor fellow had few privileges (religiously), and we must think of that. I wish had known it before. He was very much influenced and if I had known, perhaps I might have done more for him. Such things warn us to be on our guard - to do all the good we can - to exert as positive an influence as possible. It is pleasant to turn from his sudden and perhaps doubtful death, to Ella's sweet christian character - to be able to think with certainty, she is happy now.

  Our house is progressing finely. We do so enjoy the fresh pretty paper, and paint, and the rearranging things. I hope in a week or two to be at house again, and help lift something.
Completed

I am a little uncertain in my plans for the Winter. I have invited a Hartford cousin to meet me. If she comes, I shall have a quiet, cozy home time. If not, I may go away! I am in correspondence with a Mr. Home of Lancaster Farm Reform School who want me to teach in his family five hours a day. I refused at first on account of his small salary whereat he asked for what wld. I be willing to come, and I have yet to receive the answer to my reply.

          The place is said to be a very pleasant one, and as money is quite an object with us now, I may go, though Ma thinks I am hardly strong enough. So you see, I am "waiting for something to turn up" In any case, I will make you a call.
    These elections! How proud and happy and grateful we are. Won't it rejoice our soldiers in the field.
     Much love to you all from Mary D.
Completed

Miss Mary D. Dascomb
Dec. 50 ' 63

                                                                                                                 Oberlin, Lorain Co. Ohio
                                                                                                                  Dec, 20th 1863
                                                                                                                   Wed Night.
My dear Mrs Nettie,
                         Your delightful letter decided me at once to spend Christmas week with you while my Music Teacher was away, when lo, Cousin Willie prospected to spend the Holidays at home, which of course makes it out of the question for me to leave. It seems so droll to see her with a little baby, and her husband's charming little three-year-old daughter.
   The baby is prodigiously cunning - it will laugh out loud, and is only eight weeks old.
Completed

In place of myself, I sent Rutledge. I know you will like the first part it is so spicy and girlish.

  The Old Year is almost gone, and I hail the New Year, as another fine place to "turn over a new leaf." Pres. Finney preached last Sabbath on the power of God, the special gift of the Holy Spirit to christians whereby they may win souls. He says one may be a christian without it, but all christians may have it, so that a word from them may awaken and impress the sinner when the same from another would not. That is what I need. I have the most precious S. School class. Some are just beginning to do right - others have not
Completed

begun. I need so much wisdom to lead them to Christ. Pray for me.

   Love to all friends,
                     Most aff - ly-
                             Mary D.

A Happy New Year to all!
Completed

Westborough Dec 26th  1863? written in corner

My dear Cousin
 Three times since our darling Susie "went home" have I made unsuccessful attempts to write to you. I so longed for you, who have been in the school of affliction, longer than I, to comfort me; and now at Mother's request I mite try again, to answer your comforting letter to them.   Dec 27th  I found I over estimated my strength yesterday, for my heart was so full and sad I could not write. I've been striving & praying for new strength, to enable me to bear this

on side, left:
is sick with a fever, quite comfortably sick. Joshua's wife gave birth to a dead babe recently, but is getting along nicely. I think Joshua has a fine wife. It was a great disappointment to them 9the death of the child, I mean, not the fine wife) Maria & Hattie are at home. Hattie is teaching. I wish you could come and see us all. I should so love to tell you all the little things Susie said to us in her last days, so dear to us and would be to you - Will you not write me soon?  Love to all from  Cousin Anna
Completed

trial, not only with calm submission, but with heartfelt joy, believing that God has "with unerring hand" worked out "his plan" of Susie's life, and has taken her thus early to his own home. I know she is far happier now, and I trust she has formed her work. Her loving active spirit so longed to be useful while she dwelt on earth that I can but feel that she is now with Him, "in whose presence is fullness of joy." We know she is not clogged by a poor weak suffering body, often requiring rest. Oh how often she spoke of the rest of Heaven. I wish you could have seen her in her last days, so peaceful and happy, So delighted that she was "going home". She never spoke of death in any other way than going home.

Jan. 18th I would not send this old letter if I thought I should be well enough to write a whole one soon,
Completed

so I hope you will excuse this. I have been very unwell ever since dear Susie died but am more so now. I dont know whether I am rebellious and unreconciled to the will of God, or why it is I mourn so all the time, and want her with me so much. No one knows what we were to each other. I was with her the greater part of the last year of her life, and now she is in my thoughts the last thing at night & first in the morning. My physician says it's thinking of her and living over the last weeks of her life, in my thoughts that is the cause of my illness, but I cant help it. Merrick sent his little Walter, a dashing boy of five years, to stay with me, and take up my mind. He was with me six weeks. I was sorry to spare him then, but "Papa had the first claim." When I commenced  this, he was at my side
Completed

asking questions about his little cousins out west wished me to ask if they hung their stockings Christmas, and what they found in them. It took more wisdom than I possess to ans. a great many of his questions. I would send you Susie's photograph if we had it, but we could not succeed in getting a good one, she was so feeble. We have a pretty good ambrotype, & are going to have some photographs from it, and will send you one, and if I can ever get a respectable one of myself I will send it. I've tried four times. I would like yours if agreeable to you. I have a nice album, and a nice place in it for yours and all your family. Father & Mother send much love, & thanks for your kind letter. Brother Merrick is very unwell, sometimes we think will never be any better. He coughs badly. Cousin Joshua has bought his milk route in Providence; Sam Griggs

Du Quoin ILL
Du Quoin
Dec 8th 1863

My dear Mrs Metcalf
  I thank you for your very kind letter - I thank you for your remembrance & sympathy - I am always to glad to see Mr Metcalf - it reminds me of happyer days - when my children were around about me - Oh how much grace I need to say "Thy will be done" - sometimes I think my heart says it - I know that God means all this for my good - tho He takes all - it will be but a few days before I shall follow - & then - - - oh & then shall we meet on that land where the weary are at rest -   This pleasant weather Anna seems so much better - Our home for this winter is at our old place - we are boarding with a pleasant family - the care of keeping house was too much for me  It is rather lonely - tho our DuQuoin friends call often - dear ones they are

on side: You cant think how much good your kind letter did me - I am so ready to despond - to distrust have mercy oh God on my unbelief   farewell dear friend & forget not to pray for your ever friend   S Root
Completed

how kind every body is to us - every delicacy Anna has. The old school house is a dear spot still. Mr. Wood is their minister - & the church tho but few are engaged

 All the young men in the army - Mrs. Skinner has two sons there.
My time is mostly occupied in waiting upon A. She is very very feeble. - does not suffer much only from her breath which is sometimes frightful.
  I presume you have heard that last spring she was taken with a hemmorage of the lungs - apparently in health  tho the winter she had a slight cough a cold - her health has always been so uniform, that we thought she could not be sick - the laws of health was her study - very temperate in all things - but I have no doubt but it is hereditary, was taken just as Ephraim was - tho fails more rapidly.
  she spent three months, with her friend in NY. I had great hopes that would do her much good, but it did not. the bleeding continued frequently until her return & had not since any?  her flesh is wasting - she seems cheerful most of time - anticipate our return to our home in the spring. I have been afraid she would not live until spring, but she seems for a few days so much better she may be comfortable next summer.
  I am interested in your family of dear ones - may God spare them to be a blessing to you & the world.
  Some how I need more chastisement than others - it is my prayer that I may proffit by all this, - how triffling the world looks to me - there is but few that I enjoy their society. I am sorry I feel so - it seems as tho I should love to talk with you & Mr. Bradford love to them - altho I am an old woman I may live to see you with others
Completed

Elmira Feb. 25 1864

My very dear Nettie Today I came across a Rhetorical Reader having my name and the date Nov. 1836 inscribed in Father's clear firm hand. As I opened it I was back in the old school house and I could hear the voices which were wont to read the familiar passages in those days so far back on my life path.  Mr. Fitts was drilling us and ruling now and then with a rod. Do you remember him? Time has wrought many changes with us all, and scattered those who were wont to gather there far and wide. I spent about a week in Dunbarton last summer and though I enjoyed the place and my visit well it did not seem very homelike and I sadly missed most of those I loved best. I did not go into your old home; it looked pleasant as ever outside but I did not wish to see your dear mother's place vacant in that house so closely associated with her. I passed a sabbath there but Mr. Hayward
[left-hand side and top] very earnest patriotic lecture in a modest unassuming manner. By the way, have you read Bayard Taylor's Hannah Thurston ? If so what do you think of it. We have been quite interested in it. My brother has teased mother a little about being the heroine of a novel, but that Hannah's not her counterpart. We have a rarity in the family in the shape of a baby nephew at my brother's. He is five months old & very bright of course. Please give love from mother, sister & myself to your household & to your good sister. Kisses for me to the children, Wilder & Charlie. I have not forgotten and I love them all because they belong to you and I know I should for their own sake.
Completed

exchanged with Mr. Holmes from Auburn. I saw and spoke with most of those living whom we used to know, went into Dea. Parker's class in Sabbath School. It was rather strange to see anyone else acting as superintendent though Charles Rider filled the place very  well. Our family friends were pretty well though Jona Irelnd seems older than father did. I saw Mr. Colby & his wife, they seem very happy. No one lives at their old place. They are on Col. Stinson's farm & Harriet on the Bailey place near our house. I was sorry not to be able to see her. Our people thought she had a hard time & that they were poor. I called at Mr. Brigham's, found them not very well, also at Cha's Kimball's. They have two very pretty little girls. I spent about two months among friends in N. Hampshire & two more in Penn. Maine & Mass. I have never been away so long at a time during the sixteen years of my residence here but I had been feeling for the last two or three years that I must have some change or I should wholly break down so I thought I would try travelling. Sister went with me to Maine and enjoyed my first visit "down East" very
Completed

much. We were in Bangor & attended the anniversary exercises of the Seminary which were very interesting. Then we visited at Bucksport,Orland & Searsport making the acquaintance of some good cousins almost the first of our name that I ever saw. The elder members of the Thurston family in Maine were our cousins to my father, but we have had very little acquaintance with them. I enjoyed the summer on the whole very much and hoped I was benefitted by the change but after I had been at home a little while I raised a little blood and then afterwards had a severe bilious attack so that I was kept in and not able to do much for two months. I am feeling pretty well & much stronger now, still my side & chest are somewhat troublesome. I do not cough much. I have not been in school at all this year, am teaching a little now. Mother has been quite feeble part of the winter but we have managed to take care of each other mostly. My absence & sickness will explain why I have been so long in writing to you my ever dear friend. I thought to write from New England but you know it is not easy to write while visiting.
[left hand side and over main part of letter] I prize your mother & your photographs very much. Have them in my nice album which came to me on my birthday last year.  I send you one of mine, as good a one as I have ever had I think. I am rather a hard subject, I think. I am giving you too hard a lesson in patience so I'll stop.  Let me hear from you soon. Ever your own friend

                                                                                                  Mary D. T.
Completed

Sister has had so much more care than usual that she has become quite worn & wearied and has I believe fully decided not to continue the school after the close of this year in June. We cannot decide just what we shall do but probably keep house on a smaller scale just our three selves. A quiet pleasant home out of school has been one of my air castles but somehow I have not looked forward to anything with very bright anticipations of late. I feel sometimes very like a child wearied out with running, ready to lie down in the way, powerless to go farther. How much I should love to look in upon you all to-night. Your dear little ones are growing taller and wiser and better every day. I hope you have been kept free from sickness this winter.

Your father I was happy to hear was much better in health last summer.

Great preparations are making here for a fair for the Sanitary Commission. It is to be held next week and will no doubt bring many people to our midst. Our Village (or City that is to be) is already crowded by soldiers. They are constantly coming & going. When will this strife end? I fear yet that there will be a desperate struggle but I am sure that right & justice will prevail and that our government will be established on a firmer foundation. I hope that party politicians will yield their desires to the good of the whole. I am not a politician neither have I any sympathy with those of our sex called "strong minded" though they may have found only their true vocation. Anna Dickinson is to speak there soon. Have you ever heard her? She was hear last winter and gave us a
Completed

Mrs. Watson Cottagegrove Min
March 5 1864

                                                                                                      Cottage Grove. March 5th / 64

"Have pity upon me, O ye my friends for the hand of God hath touched me".

                                       We feel that we can ask for sympathy from you, dear friends, for your own hearts have bled as ours are now bleeding. Our darling little Olive has gone. Last Thursday we laid the dear dust down in the cold earth and how desolate seems our home without her. I did not know till she was gone how much she filled my heart - too much perhaps, and a loving father has taken her to himself to know that it is better for her, gone in all her innocence, and we try to think of her as she is in the presence of Jesus but it is hard to look away from our own sorrow. There is such a sense of want. "A stillness aching round."
                She was taken sick the first 

[left-hand side]Tell little May that Ollie always remembered and talked of her.
Completed

week in January - complained for two or three days of pain in her stomach we gave her the usual remedies but as they seemed to have no effect we thot she must be troubled with worms and were about sending for worm medicine when her feet and ankles commenced swelling and became in a short time very painful and so sore that she could not bear the least thing to touch them. We sent to St. Paul for a Dr. and he said that whatever the trouble was in the start it had resolved itself into rheumatism. He inquired if she had had palpitations of the heart or nose bleed saying that in children they almost always preceeded rheumatism, but she had had neither to our knowledge.

The medicine relieved her so that in forty eight hours she could stand on her feet. Dear little thing I never shall forget how happy she and Minnie were when they found she could
Completed

stand and step a little - she kept gaining till she got so she could walk all about and remained so three or four weeks but did not seem right well any of the time - she has a peculiar whiteness in her face and hands all winter which cause us some uneasiness. One evening about four weeks before she died she complained of pain in her left side. I laid my hand on to try and ease it and found her heart was beating violently - in a day or two she commenced coughing and we took her to St. Paul to see the Dr. he called it palpitation of the heart and seemed confident that he could help her soon - we proposed staying at Fathers a few days where he could see her often but he did not seem to think it necessary  and so we came home but she grew worse and we sent for him in a few days - he then called it organic disease of the heart and gave but little encouragement that he could
Completed

help her - she kept failing, seeming to wither away in our arms like a broken flower. I dont think she had any acute pain but there was a distress that she could not describe - the little heart fluttered all the time and every little vein in her neck throbbed and quivered incessantly. she sometimes asked when Spring would come. The first morning of spring dawned calm and bright - she lay on the bed quite still for a while - then she seemed to be disturbed and wanted to be carried round - her father took her and carried her round a few minutes - she called for water and after she drank seemed to be trying to throw up wind - he sat down with her and rubbed her back and she bent her head forwards - breathed a few minutes and was gone. She was beautiful in death - all the distressed look was gone from the little face and there was a faint smile round her mouth

                 But I fear I am wearying you. I did not intend to write so much when I commenced but you know " but the fullness of the heart the mouth speaketh. 
                     Please write soon as convenient we are always glad to hear from you. Please give our best respects to your mother and Dr. DeWitts family. 
                                                                                                   Yours with much love
                                                                                                       M.W. Watson.
Completed

Thursday, July 14th 1864?

 What do you think of me, my dear Mrs Metcalf that two weeks should have passed since the reception of your very pretty present and no acknowledgement of it: Please lay it to my ignorance and not ingratitude - I believe I would rather you would think it shat? that has caused the delay. I intended to write you before Mr P. came home  I felt like it and I thought it might be acceptable, but it kept me busy to keep Mr P posted - and I did not feel much in the writing order - But when he came and gave me just what I have wanted so long and never had - I thought I should write directly but one thing has happened so directly after another that writing time has seemed so hard to find. I shall prize your gift very

this continues on next page
sideways, on left side
for them all - I have Wilder to look at and often I see him too I wish I had yourself & husband  Tell Wilder I do not wish to see him or hear of his standing Lovers? than 2nd once next year and he ? must commence the first day to do it.  Love to Miss Berber? and will you johen? give love to Hattie Dewitt and kindly remember me to Mr & Mrs Dr Dewitt - I have not forgotten their kindness to strangers - I am anxious to hear how church matter stands.  There are elements in our church in E that do not combine very well - May 3 unclear words Power? unclear words and all be peace - Our church here have in fact dismissed their minister But he is still preaching and all is quiet - But I unclear words
With much love  Clara Parker

much. It is so neat and so servicable. I have thought of you so often when looking at it that now the gift and the giver are always connected. I did not wish a return however I have received so many favors from your hand that I could not reply it only makes one feel your kindness more - some day I may be able to return your hospitality. I thank you for all, and your kind husband too. May Heaven reward you for all your deeds of love. I feel that it is so.

   I am not sorry to see Mr.Parker as you may imagine. I had all the pleasure of seeing home friends before he came and then of welcoming him, and the tokens of remembrance he brought were truly pleasing. My associations with Elyria are mostly of a happy nature - a few that I care not to think of I laugh over and forget. Though when I feel I did not do my whole duty I do not try to forget but think of them as lessons for the future.
Completed

Vacation is passing rapidly and pleasantly. only think six more weeks and we enter a new field of duty. new acquaintances to be made - I do not anticipate it. I do not think I am the right one to change friends so often - My Zanesville friends are as dear to me today as they were the day I left them - And I know it will be so of my Elyria friends - Mrs Metcalf not the least. And is she willing with all her cares to write occasionally to me - Not that there is any danger of my forgetting her - But 'twould be pleasant? to have that proof. One of the most precious boons God has given us - of her remembrance  I offer no inducements as a correspondent  There are some things I can do - others I cannot among them - write interesting letters. So that any request is purely from selfish motives - Anything come?ed? with E. will be interesting even if you do not have? the Metcalf family - I'd like to see every one of them - from the "garde man of the house" to the little new one. A good wish

Auburn, NY
Sept 24
1864
Elyria

                                                                                                                       Auburn Sept. 24th 1864.

Dear Mrs. Metcalf

    I do not "owe" you any letter and you will doubtless be somewhat surprised at receiving one from me, from New York when (if you think of me at all) you think that I am in Illinois.
   But true it is that I am here. I have been here nearly a month visiting my relatives and shall probably stay several weeks longer.
   I have always had a desire to see you
Completed

and the thought came to me to visit you on my return home. If I mistake not Elyria is on the Southern Rail Road and if convenient for you I think I will take that road home and visit you.

 I thought it best to write not having heard from you in so long a time, that possibly you might have changed your place of residence.
   I came here in company with acquaintances but expect to go home alone. I am enjoying myself very much.
  Would you please write when you receive this as I would like to hear from you before deciding which route to take.
                           Much love and many kind wishes from
                                                                                    Eliza E. Paddock

Direct to

          Auburn, Cayuga Co. 
                          N.Y.

Care: Alfred Smith.

Auburn Oct. 20th 1864.

Dear Mrs. Metcalf,

                       Your letter was received in due season and having decided upon my route home I thought it best to write and inform you.
                     I expect to start for home next Tuesday, consequently cannot visit you although I should very much enjoy it if it were convenient - but another time will do just as well.
               I expect to travel alone as the friends that I came with have gone home.
              I received a letter from Mother
Completed

last night. They were all well at home, and send much love to you as they expected that I would visit you.

    People seem to be very much engaged about the coming election and are holding meetings nearly every day.
    I really hope that "Lincoln" will be elected. If he is not, I fear the consequences. The country will surely be ruined.   
    Dinner is almost ready and I must close.
    Write at your earliest convenience and believe me
                                           Ever your friend
                                                             Eliza Paddock

In great haste.

                               Direct to Lockport, Ill.
Completed

Eliza Paddock
                                                                                                           Homer May 1, 1865
                                                                                                            Elyria, Ohio                                                                                  

                                                                                                                                         Lockport May 1st 1865

Dear Mrs. Metcalf

   Your last letter written Feb. 27th lies before me. I intended answering it sooner - but have been negligent.
   I reached home the 4th of Nov. A cousin came with me and we enjoyed the journey very much. 
   I should have been glad to meet you had it been possible - perhaps I shall see you some time. Can you not make us a visit this summer? We should be delighted to have you.
Completed

You would not recognize Homer (or Yankee Settlement as it used to be called) I think I wrote to you about our Church. We now have a fine Double Reed Melodeon . We held a festival to raise the funds.
  I saw Mr. Knapp's people last week. They were inquiring about you and wished me to give you their respects, when I wrote.
  What terrible news we have had of late. What a loss the nation has sustained in the death of our President.
  Are you not glad that the murderer has been killed: I wish he might have been hung. Of course it is all for the best. God knows just what is best for his people.
  You ask if I ever think of teaching school. I have - but father is greatly opposed to my leaving home, so I suppose I shall not teach. I think I should like to
Completed

with me one or two terms.

 I am now taking Music lessons of a lady in Lockport. It takes a goodly portion of my time.
 It is raining quite fast to-day. Making it seem glowing without, but cozy and pleasant within, just the time to write is'nt it.
  I'll try to tell you the little items of news of the neighborhood.
  Mr. Brace Rowley's people lost their oldest son three weeks since. He died in a congestive chill. Olive R. or Mrs. Lynk is quite sick.
  Cousin George has been quite sick but is now better. Mrs. Wells is going to Canada visiting - she starts tomorrow. All other old acquaintances are well.
  It is getting late. I must close. I am always glad to hear from you. Please write soon.
                         Truly & lovingly yours

Mother & father send love                            E E Paddock
Completed

Oberlin June 17th / 65

Dear Mrs. Metcalf,

                     How long it is since we have met! Husband and I have for some weeks been talking of making an effort to get out to Elyria soon. My brother Daniel's wife is now in Oberlin. I want her to see you, wh. she desires very much.
  My plan is to ride out with her next week - perhaps Wedn., and spend a few hours with you. Br. Leonard has visited us recently, and will return home by way of Oberlin. He went from us to visit his son & sister Martha in Iowa. He may be here again next week - and prevent our going to E. the day we set to go.
                                                    In haste
                                                           Yours truly,
                                                                      M. P. Dascomb

[left-hand side and top] Annie may ride out to E. with us. She longs to see you & the children, "baby especially" she says - She sends love.
