Dryden Springs  Aug 3d 1865

My very dear Nettie - It is a long time since I have written to or heard from you and my apology must be that much of the time I have scarcely felt equal to writing. You will wonder why my letter is not as usual from Elmira as I dout? myself that I am here at a resort for invalids. It can hardly be called a Water Cure though there is a fine sulpher Spring and the water is freely used for drinking and bathing. you know that I have not been well for sometime; last Nov. I had some congestion of my left lung and after that several severe bilious attacks so that I went out very little through the winter. I have gained through the summer but I wanted to be away this month and so I have come here to be for a little time under the care of Miss Nivison who has the reputation of being a skillful physician. I like her very much though she is a character by herself. The place is a delightfully quiet country town and the this text continues on next page

on left side, across top, and right side, in different handwriting:
Mother and sister would join with me in love to you all.  Dear friend Nettie  I know you never forget me.  Will you not ask for me strength & submission for whatever is before me. I wish I could see you  May we meet where there is no more hurting. If we may not May our Father bless you and yours. Ever your friend & sister   Mary D. Thurston
Completed

family which is not large very pleasan[t]. Everything is made as homelike as possible - cut off by Miss N & her two sisters. Miss N. examined my lungs yesterday and thinks there is no active disease now but that the upper part of the left one is nearly useless. There will of course be a tendency to disease though she says she sees no reason why with care I may not have comfortable health for years.  I cannot hope to be as strong as before and the thought of being weak and unable to do is trying but if my heavenly Father sees best thus to discipline me I trust shall be cheerfully submissive to his will and have strength for whatever work there is for me to do. The time has never seemed to come when I could feel free from care. The school was given up last year in June but we were obliged to arrange for housekeeping immediately. Sister rented our part of the house to our niece Mary who married a Mr Gardiner and boarded with them for the use of the furniture. Thus Mother and I were left by ourselves so we decided to take some rooms upstairs & keep house. It was not just the way I would have chosen
Completed

but seemed best under the circumstances. Since the weather became warmer we have taken our meals with Mary though I think when I return we shall be by ourselves if I can get some one to help me. Mother is still pretty well though I can see that she has failed in strength, this far we have been able to care for each other though it is one of my trials that I am not able to do all I would like for her comfort. We are more now to each other than ever since no one seems to need us.  My brother's wife died the last of June and Clara is left with the care of housekeeping and the four younger children, the youngest not two years. Sister is at home now, intends going East soon to spend some time. She was absent five months last fall and winter in N. Hampshire, Mass. & N. Y. City. I was at home all last summer and have been most of the times this until I came here shall probably stay two or three weeks longer. I wanted very much to visit you and other friends West but do not think it right to leave mother long at a time. I want to see you and your dear ones so much. I hope you are all
Completed

well and that the children are and so are a great comfort and help their parents. Wilder must be a large boy and Charlie too. Kiss them all for me. My niece Mary has a dear babe eight months old, a great pet with us all.   

  How rapidly events come crowding upon each other during a few months in our country. The war is ended and with it slavery destroyed yet it still seems almost impossible that order and good feeling can prevail at present. How comforting to know that God rules over all and will cause all things to work together for good and His own glory.
 Has your father been to visit you and how is his health? We have not heard from Dunbarton lately. There is a Miss Ward here, teacher in the College at Elmira who was at Holyoke when Sarah Wingate died, says she was with her most of the time for the last two days. Do you know any thing of the family now? I am coming to the end of my sheet and the breakfast bell will ring soon so I must close. We have only two meals. breakfast at eight and dinner at two. Let me hear from you as soon as you can.
Completed

Hattie DeWitt Gaylord
Hartford Conn
Nov 18th 1865
Dear Aunt Nettie.

 I was truly glad to receive your kind letter & made many good reasons to answer immediately but my some after its arrival we were very suddenly called home by sickness & while there I of course could do no writing. On my return I found more than enough to do in cleaning my house, which I persisted in doing myself, I have been pretty tired some days but can now rejoice on my bloodless victory over woodwork &  windows.  I have a good long day to myself for work not interupted by dinner to get - sometimes it is most to long & I look for six o'clock very impatiently. Mr Gaylord spends
Completed

with me, except Saturday evening when he is obliged to be at the store. We usually spend the evening in reading & I enjoy it very much after being all day alone. I have made very few acquaintances as yet. Those I have met are very pleasant.

  I have been out but very little, my home duties sometimes keeping me in & sometimes inclination. I started to hear Wendell Phillips lecture, but was disappointed. I was quite anxious to see him. Mr. Chapin is our next lecturer. I hope to hear him. Dr. Bushnell preaches at the South Church tomorrow. I hope to hear him. I like Mr. Parker very much. I have not become connected with any Sabbath School as they have their Sabbath School in the afternoon, it is not possible for me to go then; it is too far to go three times a
Completed

day. Who has my old class at home & what about them? In what classes are the little cousins? I remember having heard Carrie Putnam speak of her brothers & would like to have met him. What is Carrie's address I would like to write her. I am glad that I am missed by some at home but feel that I have so happy a home that I ought to be very thankfull & contented, & I am contented. Clouds very seldom visit my face & then merely from an anxiety to do the right thing.

 Last Thursday ended the so called "honeymoon" but we both resolved to be careful, in the future, of giving offense as we have ? in the past. What do you hear from Lerrie Stickney? & where is Grandmother now? I had not heard of the death of Mrs. Beachey until you wrote. There has been quite a change in Elyria
Completed

in these three months.  You can imagine perhaps how much I would like to see Aunt Maria & the children. I hope they may be persuaded to remain in Elyria. I am very glad your little ones remember me. give a great deal of love or kisses (which they doubtless would value more) to each of them. I would to see Charley's sunny face. Aunt, can I not have a better picture of you & one of Uncle? I have none of him, nor of Charley. I can imagine you busy mending to night; I would like to look in upon you. When shall I see you all again? Give love to all who inquire, to Grand mother & to all at Uncle Charles', Aunt Nettie do such as often as you can - - your letters, do me good. I would love to hear from Uncle Isaac, love to him. Mr. Gaylord joins me in kind remembrances to one & all of the friends.

                                                                                                Lovingly yours
                                                                                                  Hattie Gaylord

[upside down] A good pen here ?

Oberlin, Nov. 23d / 65

My dear Mrs. Metcalf,

       Perhaps you may have heard that Mary is to sail for Rio Jan. this winter as companion to Mrs. Julia Finney Monroe*, and teacher of the children. She has just gone to Cleveland today to make the purchases for her outfit. But we are in real distress for an efficient seamstress  to come right into the family and help us three or four weeks. I have made enquiries at Painesville Cleve & Sandusky without success. Yesterday I heard that such a lady could be found in a Miss Hopkins, now with Mrs. Arthur Ely of Elyria. If she is a competent individual, could I possible procure her? If not for 4 wks. cd. I for two - or even one? The expense of sending for her wd.

[left side, top and right side]Dr. D. is lecturing in Cleve for the winter. Anna has just had an invitation to spend the winter in Granville Ill. with Miss Hopkins, our former boarder. She may go if an offer occurs after Mary leaves.  M. thought to be all ready and packed by Christmas.

Julia is to be married at Thanksgiving.
Completed

hardly pay for one week, but we are in a desperate straight. If Mrs. Ely is depending on her services, could she delay her work for a little? Of course I have no claim in her benevolence, more than any other stranger. She is a little acquainted with Mary. Had I known the real burden of fitting out a child for 2 1/2 years, I would not have consented that Mary shd. have had the application. As it was, I did make it one of the serious objections to her going - as I am now situated.

  I thought of Mrs. Mary Crowe - but I know not where she is - and then she has young children. If you are confined at home, so that you cannot see about Miss H. or any other one, will Mrs. Dr. Strong serve me? You might send this note to her. Mary must see you before she goes if possible, but our bad travelling is coming on.
                                                                                                                  With much love to you all
                                                                                                                           M.P. Dascomb

[left-hand side] Can you drop me a line soon?

Oberlin, Feb. 2d. / 66

My very dear Mrs. Metcalf,

                                        I do not know whether or not Mary found time to answer your letter, which brought the sad news of your dear Mother's death. It is difficult to realize that we shall see her no more below. She was very dear to us- how much dearer to you, her children! I know you will miss her so much. I trust our dear Heavenly Father will make up your loss, by filling your souls with his love.
   We, too, are now feeling our dear Mary's absence. She left us two weeks ago, next Mond. noon. The party sailed from Baltimore in the packet Lapwing, the following Sat. We had a let. by the pilot - dated Sab. A.M. from Cape Henry. M. was in good spirits considering the circumstances - for she was just tasting the discomfort of sea sickness. But she writes

[left-hand side and top] widow needing a home, with sufficient health & skill to do, as well as mostly plan the work for a family of 5 or 6 would answer our purpose well. We would pay more wages than is ordinarily paid now for good help, which is, I believe, two dollars per week. We succeeded in getting Mary's outfit ready, as we had more time than was provided us. Our last mantuamaker fitted & made all the waists of the dresses and plet? on the skirts. The woman from Sandusky failed me - but I obtained a nice seamstress at plain sewing. I did much sewing
Completed

in the midst of risks and dismal thought, there is rest "God is on the Ocean the same as on the land." Will not you and your dear husband pray for her, especially during that long and perhaps perilous voyage? She may need our prayers still more, should she arrive safely in Brazil. M. had no great expectations from her new prospects. She decided calmly the question of going, as she would any other matter, it being according to the advice of her new friends in Vassar Coll., who although they were loth to part with her, thought it a fine opportunity for a young lady. We, her parents, left her to her own decision, stating things for & against as far as we could discern them. Mary is tenderly attached to her friends, and to leave them, for so long a time, was more than a heart, less brave than hers could bear. She always expressed the greatest love ad gratitude for you and Mr. Metcalf, whose interest in her behalf, especially when teaching in Elyria, she fully appreciated.

  You are aware, perhaps, of our latest plans respecting my labors in the Inst. the coming year. I am to spend my nights at home, and at the Boarding Hall, wh. will be opened for young ladies at the beginning of the Spring term. Of course I shall greatly need efficient help in the domestic dep. at home - and have as yet no prospect in that direction that is satisfactory. It may be in vain to ask you if you can give me any light in that quarter. 
                   A middle-aged woman, say a 

[left-hand side and top] on my machine. We hoped to see you before M. left and again when the fine sleighing was. We will have a jubilee when the rail road is completed. With much love to you all. Yours truly M.P. Dascomb    Husband is lecturing at Clev. New Med. College but spends every Sab. & Monday at home. Annie sends much love. Both she and I battle bad colds now. I have send to the Bookstore for more paper. Excuse this crowded half sheet.

                                                                                                                                     Hartfert
                                                                                                                                      March 15 -/66
                                                                                                                                                         Hartford Conn.
                                                                                                                                                         March 15th 1866.

Dear Aunt Nettie,

          I meant to have seated myself to write you immediately after dinner but have been prevented from doing so until now & it is nearly five o'clock, only a little over an hour & then Orrin will be home. Sometimes the days seem very long & this had been very long to me though I have been quite busy. I have washed, ironed & baked this week & am glad to feel that it is done for one week more. You may think that I can have but little to bake but I find food disapeares quite fast with only three to eat. This has been a beautiful day, if I had only had had some place to run without cleaning up I should not have remained in all day. I miss my running in places very much indeed, & shall
Completed

more I presume as Spring advances.
As it is I stay almost wholly at home have very little inclination to go out on the street - with nothing to call me there. This is moving time & nearly all are on the stir: we have decided to move but have not made a decision upon the tenement. Our object in moving is to be nearer the store so that Orrin can come home to dinner, & nearer Church. Our deaf & dumb neighbors moved out yesterday & you can hardly imagine what a relief it as to me to see them go.
Mrs. Weeks became vexed at something I do not know what & from that time she has seemed to seize every opportunity to annoy me. She threw all her slops & swill from her kitchen window frequently by letting the dirty water run the whole length of mine, & in the same way from the bedroom. And then the noises she made to the child became very tiresome to me, but enough of this.
Completed

I had a long & very interesting letter from Mary Hall last night; nearly all taken up with an account of the meetings & the religious interest there at home. You do not know how I long to be at home when I hear those accounts. It seems as if I could not stay away - the news seems almost incredible to me & oh so glorious. I do so hope all the new converts may be earnest & steadfast; I cannot help thinking as I wrote how it would have rejoiced Grandmother's eyes to have seen this. Certainly her prayers have been answered. Yes indeed I do long to hear Father speak. I think there is no place where one feels so much a stranger as in Church or prayer meeting. I have found it so in my experience. I have tried to write to Carrie ever since I received your letter but have not found the time yet, - think I shall this week. When you write to George & Frannie give love to them & tell them I should
Completed

delight to visit them sometimes & will hope I may. I often think of the dear children one & all of them & I miss them much. Tell them I have not forgotten them & that I love them as I did when at home & Aunty I do wish I could see you, that either you could come to me or I go to you. I want to talk to you ever so much, writing does not answer the purpose at all. Wish we might have helped you eat that same big turkey, we would have done our very best , had we been there. Aunty will you please hand enclosed note to mother. Please give a great deal of love to all the friends to Uncle Isaac especially. I do not feel that this is a fair return for your long letter but you know I have few items for letter writing while you have so many. I must stop now & get tea for Orrin with much love goodbye.

                                                                                Your loving niece
                                                                                               Hattie Gaylord.
Completed

Mrs. Hattie Gaylord
Hartford Conn.
July 22, 1866

                                                                                                                            Hartford Conn.
                                                                                                                             July 22nd 1866.

Dear Aunt Nettie,

                              Your very kind letter was received some time since & I have thought of you often since & have desired to reply but circumstances have not permitted. Your letter came just as I was going home for a short visit, & since my return I have been too weary to write. The weather for the last two weeks has been intensely warm & has been very hard for me to endure. I enjoyed my stay in the country very much although it was short, but the ride there & back tired me very much. The weather now is much cooler & I am enjoying it very much indeed. I do not go out much but have quite enough exercise in the
Completed

house at present, for I find I am not as elastic as I once was. I am very well now - only weigh one hundred & twenty (my usual weight is one hundred) I hear from home quite frequently but not near as often as I would like to. I have enjoyed seeing the friends from home very much & through them I have learned many items of interest that I have not learned through letters. I do want to see them all at home so much but I fear it will be a long time before I shall. I am very glad your little ones get along so nicely. Whom do you leave them with while Uncle is away? I would love to see George & Frannie very much & I have a plan in my head to run up & make them a visit sometime in the future not very far distant. Are you acquainted with Mrs. Bird, the sister of Mrs. Dascomb? She lives quite near
Completed

us & I would like to be acquainted with her, but hear that as a family they hold themselves quite high & do not like to make the advances. I have made many kind friends since I came up into this part of the city - they are all so kind to me & I know and fee that it is because my Heavenly Father sends those blessings to me & not because I deserve them. All of Orrin's friends are just as kind to me as they can be & I can not tell you how good & kind Orrin is to me. I wish you knew him. I know you would like him. Aunt Nettie I want to see you very much & hope that I may. It will not be in the least inconvenient (on my account) but I shall not be able to accomodate you as we would like to but if you will take us as we are, we will try to make you comfortable & shall be most happy to see you. Do not disappoint us. I do not expect to be sick till the last of the month - shall have help
Completed

next week. My sewing is nearly finished & so I am going to take thing as easy as I can. Remember me to George & Fannie & accept love from Orrin & myself. Hoping to see you soon I remain as ever your loving niece

                                                                                 Hattie Gaylord.
